												I can without hesitation reccomend this game. As of now I have 147 hours of playtime which is probably more than the average person would get out of it. It is not without it's flaws but in my opinion the flaws are not game breaking in the least.Do not be put off by the first mission. The very first mission is a mandatory, linear, and all around just not very fun. It serves to teach you the mechanics without distracting you from the goal. There are other missions just like it which I feel are too linear, but nowhere near as bad as the first. I think this tutorial mission put off too many people who never got to the next one to find how "open" it could be and what the possibilites were like. It's not unbearable but it's so un-indicative of how most of the game goes and what makes it so good.The menu system is pretty clunky. It seems to be really geared toward console gamepad controls. It's a small nitpick and you get used to it quite quickly but it can get annoying if you need to switch items a lot in rapid succession.There is one fault with the rating system I will go into detail about next. There is a way to cause "accidents". You push someone off a cliff/down the stairs/whatever, or maybe you rig something to fall apart or explode suddenly to cause something large to crush them. Now while I love the concept and usually it is brilliant, there are problems. For example, I remember one instance where I wanted to get all accidents for the Silent Ghost rating (the highest paid rating possible). Well, pushing the guy down the stairs was the best way. So I push him and then he falls kind of slowly in what looks like a crawl down the steps. Then what happens? Apparently he didn't "crawl fall" enough and gets up and starts to shoot me along with everyone else. I had to reload and do this many, many times for it to finally work correctly. So I have a little problem with that but it happens relatively few times in the course of a playthrough.So with the things that bother me out of the way, let me lose myself in the seemingly endless things that I love about his game. Starting with the Rating System. Now with this system you are awarded cash and a title depending on many factors including whether you did the optional objectives, how many innocents you knocked out/killed, how many times you alerted guards, how many bodies were found, how many "accidents" occured, what gun was used the most, how many shots hit their target, how accurate you were, noise level, violence level, and a whole bunch of other factors. Most of these come as a straight spreadsheet of info, but some are in the brilliant newspaper front page that you get afterwards. It gives a summary as an article of what you did, whether you silently exectuted the target/s quietly, or went and killed hundreds of people. Seeing the different ratings you can get for accomplishing certain levels of violence, silence, and ways to kill people, really increases replayability and makes certain "runs" pretty fun. Sometimes I just try to see how many people I can kill with a kitchen knife and still finish the mission. Or maybe i'll see how many accidents I can cause.The custom loadout is really well done, but it has one flaw. You are limited in that you can only bring one weapon that you acquired from a mission. Like if you leave a mission with a Mosin Nagant sniper rifle then it becomes available with limited ammo for taking you with you on a mission. But what I don't like is that you can't have 2 rifles, 2 pistols, or 2 sub machine guns. You have 1 pistol, 1 rifle, and 1 submachinegun with no exceptions. I would rather have traded some of the other gadgets i didn't need for more flexibility but it simply wasn't an option. Still, the loadout system is fine despite that limitation. If you're really good then all you need are the syringes and the fiber wire most of the time anyway.The writing is so hilarious. It is mostly self aware of how crappy it is at times and does it for comedic effect. Other times the writing is really witty and feels very real. Mostly everyone fits some sort of stereotype, almost insultingly so, but it has such a charm when a sailor with sideburns on the Mississippi says "Get lost Chum Lee." in a Cajun accent. This game has so much character in the characters if that makes sense. It feels very real, but at the same time it's so very surreal too.The soundtrack is to die for. No really, it's like really well done mostly because of Jesper Kyd when he was, in my opinion, at his peak. It's a very teasy mix of classical and electronic rythums depedning on the mood and what is happening. Easily one of my favorite soundtracks.Another thing I love about this game is the attention to detail. I'm always finding something new. I found out last time I played Curtains Down (a mission in which you are at a french opera house during a practice night). There is a guard constantly "patroling" with a group of people as a tour guide. This guard takes a break and goes into this small closet-like room. When he does you can quickly knock him out/kill him and take his clothes. So when you come back out the group starts following you as if you are the new guide. After a mintue or so of not talking to them they of course disperse sounding agitated in french. It's this kind of nuance and possiblity of discovery that helps me come back to play and see what else I can uncover. I hate to spoil a later mission but for example you walk into a high class party and the singer is absolutely, positively awful. First time I played I didn't even really notice I thought that maybe the game did it for a laugh, but then later you find out that she is the secret assassin there to kill you. That sort of blew my mind when I found out and yet another testament to the small things. You'll notice too that when you kill a contract they will appear in the main menu's chapel sitting in various spots as if attending. I could go on forever about all this little stuff but I think you get it.I can honestly say it's one of my favorite games of all time.  Try it.

content:
9, 2014
												I think at this point most people who know anything about the series have heard that Blood Money is the best. It is. The levels are surprisingly big, for a start. Well, they're not huge compared to say, any shooter, but they're packed full of stuff. Even on my fourth playthrough I still found new things. New ways to kill people, new ways to hide their bodies, etc. It's also very open ended. There's refreshingly little guidance. No annoying helper character telling you which way to go, no big floating arrows, it just puts you in an area with instructions to ruin some poor sod's day and off you go. Yeah there are some optional hints to buy but besides that you're pretty much left to work it out for yourself. This approach does cause some problems, sadly. It means that save scumming is heavily encouraged, as there's a lot you can only work out through experimentation. Often it's not entirely clear which disguises will allow you in which area, but thankfully you're usually allowed to leave the area and find another way in rather than being shot on sight, so that's handy, but it's less forgiving with the actual kills. The NPCs are very unpredictable. It's quite likely that another character will walk in while you're busy killing someone, and there's no way to see it coming or prevent them from spotting you once you've started. Once you have been spotted it's usually easiest to just reload a save. You can try to shoot your way out, but while you can finish the level this way it won't be nearly as satisfying. You can also leg it and put on a different disguise, but a couple of times the guards would shoot me on sight even after doing this. Why? I don't know. This sort of thing can get very frustrating at times, but thankfully the positives of the game outweigh this. Walking into a building, killing your target with little extra damage and walking out again unnoticed is a great feeling. The newspapers at the end of every level add to the sense of acheivement, sure, but they are pretty limited. There's only a couple of things they can say. It'll say what weapon you used, whether you killed anyone besides the target and if there were any witnesses. It'll also criticise your aiming skills every damn time because the guns are just shockingly inaccurate. Even when I was sure I hit every shot it'll still tell me that I missed like 50 of them. I felt insulted.One final note: the notoriety system. The basic idea that you get ranked based on how well you performed the kill and how many witnesses you left is good, but in practice it basically changes nothing. You can just pay to have it reduced, and I could easily afford it every time. It supposedly means that NPCs will be more suspicious of you but as I never actually had any notoriety I don't know how true this is.Despite these issues the game is still great. There are few games that do anything similar. Even the older Hitman games kind of feel more like spy games than assassin games. You'd generally deal with the military rather than being in any public areas, whereas Blood Money offers a wide range of levels in which to be a total ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥. There's just nothing else like it and it's a whole lot of fun.

content:
y 4, 2013
												Although I did not expect much of this Hitman iteration, it turned out to be more than just decent. Hitman: Blood Money is by some considered to be 'the better' Hitman game. Although it obviously has an edge over its predecessors as far as graphics and sound effects are concerned, it did a lot of things right.The graphics are decent for its time. While there are definitely some graphics glitches (most ragdoll related), it does not fail to immerse the player. The effects of lighting has been taken advantage of and at this point in the game development industry there's a healthy emphasis on textures except for skyboxes.The gameplay is solid and has only minor glitches that you will likely not even trigger unless you start experimenting. Regardless, none of the glitches you will run into should break the game or your perception of the atmosphere and storyline. And don't get me wrong, it had the potential to go terribly wrong here: the gameplay hooks in on the story and immersion, it could not exist without the storyline, and the storyline would not be convincing without the mechanics this game has to offer. Luckily there's nothing to be afraid of in this regard.The music is fitting and blends the environment and story together. A proper use of sounds and quality voice acting make it the story much more enjoyable. Buy it if you haven't played it yet! Hitman: Blood Money is one of those classics that you should try at least once. It is a good quality game that today's videogame industry should consider looking into as reference material.

content:
ry 20, 2015
												Hitman is one of the few stealth games that I can actually sit down and play. I don't play stealth games because of my lack of patience and stealth games are usually pretty linear or bad nowadays, but Hitman is one of the few series that still has some life in it.I remember playing this game first on the Xbox 360, it was the very first game I played on the new machine and was the first 18 game I ever played. I have fond memories of playing this game, so it does hold a dear spot in my heart. But I'm not going to be talking about the Xbox 360 version, or the console game for that matter, I'll be talking about the PC game, which was released on 30th May 2006.I think what you'll notice straight off for the Steam version is that you can't access the internet or chat, or is that just me? I mean, that's pretty damn big, I like to talk to my friends over Steam while I play games, but this game has disabled that, a lot of other games have that problem too, not necessarily with older titles but with newer, indie games too.Hitman Blood Money follows the story of Agent 47, an assassin who arrives in the United States (in this game). Narrated cutscenes drive the story, through the form of an interview, where a journalist interviews a former Director of the FBI. The story spans over the course of two years, the first mission being a-No Spoilers-ish.The graphics, I must say still stand up today in my eyes, but graphics shouldn't turn you off playing a game, that's just stupid. The detail shown on the character models and background is aesthetically pleasing, it always seems to fit the mission perfectly. The missions are all open ended and can be completed in any way you want, ranging from stealth and timing to guns blazing. I went for a stealth option on one mission, which ended up with me stealing a guards clothes, finding a shotgun, garrotting the target, hiding in a closet until the second target came into view, shot him in the face and then ran to a plane as the whole world's military force got nearer to me.This is most certainly the best Hitman game.The game is fun and for £6.99 you're definitely getting your moneys worth.Hitman Blood Money gets an 8/10

The best thing about this game is you can play to your style. Be silent or kill everyone on the map if you like. Get money, upgrade weapons and buy gadgets etc (nothing stupid like lasar watches). My critism for this game is there isn't that much replayability. I cant see playing more then around 40 hours. It only took me 14 to complete it on normal. But for its age its brilliant and i highly recommend it.  8.5/10

												It was a dark and cold night, browsing through steam looking at all the different deals with $7 in my wallet and a dusty libary I came across the hitman series in sale, looking through the avaliable purchases I thought to my self, 'Why is hitman: Blood Money rated higher than hitman: Absoloution? surely the newer version should be improved overall?' I decided to first buy absolotuion thinking it would turn out better but after seeing it would take about a day to download I gazed over at blood money and thought why not buy it... When blood money finished downloading and started the game had blown my mind. Hitman: Blood Money is one of the best stealth games I have seen in awhile, better than some next gen games that have recently came out it showed me that age may not always effect the quality of the game. Hitman: Blood Money Cons and Pros Gameplay - 9.5/10+ Disguises works perfectly unlike some other hitman games (Im looking at you Hitman: Absoloution)+ Very large amount of ways to tackle and complete the mission + Variety of melee weapons that can be picked up and used+ Depending on how well you played will effect the final rating of the level and will change the newspaper article and the end of the level which is fun to read ( For example if the player shot a weapon and it missed alot of your targets the newspaper will comment on the skill saying it was of an untrained marksman or such)+ Variety of ways to get rid of a body+ Can kill people or choose to not kill people by sedating them (By people I mean non-targeted people).+ Upgrades to custom weaponary and tools are useful.- Can be very frustrating as some assassinations can be quite difficult - The A.I can start to glitch out when the player is hiding inside a closet. They will sometimes just stand outside the closet or run at it until the player comes out.- Controls are akward in default but you can change them.Graphics 6.5/10- The graphics are dated but not horrible.- Character models lose alot of graphical quality when player is far away, I saw this commonly in the Crow mission.U.I  - 9/10+ Simple Design+ Can choose to go into first person view or third person view at any time.Storyline - 6/10+ Has a good and entertaining ending- There is no real story line aside from 2 characters which talk about the targets you kill in the game and how the police reacted in response.I would recommend this game to someone who is thinking of buying a hitman game but cant choose which one or to someone who enjoys stealth games. worth every single penny.  thanks for reading.

												This is the best Hitman game currently for sale. Obviously some of the controls and gameplay mechanics are a little dated, and the graphics are definitely showing their age, but the level design, options for dealing with each mission, and no-BS mission delivery system are all superb.The levels are huge, freely roamable, and logical. Stealth is rewarded but if you're just trying to finish the game, outright violence works fine, too. As long as you get the job done.Free of the goofy cartoonish personalities and faux-dramatic emotional story of Absolution, Blood Money's story takes a backseat to the actual mechanics of hunting people down and killing them. How you complete the job is up to you, as it should be. Plan your own route, choose your equipment, observe and recon before taking action.The downsides: some of the controls take some getting used to, the AI has some unexpected behaviours (which usually result in them shooting you for some infraction you weren't aware carries the death penalty, such as forgetting to wear a costume to the costume party), and, in my opinion, some of the early-game unmodified weapons are just so poor that they are almost unuseable (the sniper rifle before it is upgraded, for example).Still, if you like games of patience, skill, and outwitting, plus killing people, this is the purest form of Agent 47 currently available.I am looking forward to Hitman 5 this year, which promises to undo many of the mistakes of Absolution, but I'll believe it when I see it.

content:
y 29, 2015
												If you've never played the Hitman games, get this one. If you have played 'em, but haven't played this one, get this one.Hitman Blood Money is one of those games that people really disliked when it came out, but really pine after years later.It's a strange old game, and there's a few interesting quirks that you'll quickly notice and probably find funny.Let's start with the Gameplay, as that's where HBM really shines. The reason Hitman games are so fun are because of what they require from the player; an inimitable combination of patience, problem solving and timing. HBM is without a doubt the pinnacle of this 'watch, plan, wait, execute' style of gameplay. The infinitely replayable open-ended structure of each of the levels, the scaled timing of each individual NPC's movements and routines, the strange and often unexpected events that randomly catch you off guard and the peculiar brand of dark humour, subtle social satire and movie cliches that fills the game are what make HBM such a classic.My favourite way of playing this game is to enter a level, then explore it, sneak through the restricted areas using disguises or distractions, find the target(s) and watch their every move, plan a way of offing them to make it look like an accident, then casually walk to the escape route whilst nobody's any the wiser to your involvement, and the newspapers that 'review' your performance afterward just list an accident as opposed to a murder or a killing spree.Ah, but i suppose there are a few downsides to the game, and as most players of Hitman know, this comes as no surprise.The physics engine can be (and has always been in any Hitman game) a bit eccentric; There are times that the limbs of K.O. characters flop about uncontrollably if they're being dragged on uneven ground, and occasionally objects clip through parts of the environment in strange and egregious ways. thankfully none of this is game breaking, merely peculiar. The AI can also go a bit screwy on occasion; enemies seeing through disguises can every once in a blue moon happen unexpectedly with no underlying cause, enemies can become suspicious of you even when there's no reason to be, or my favourite, security guys opening fire into a crowd of civilians you're suspected of escaping through (oh, wait.. they do that in the new one too :p).The graphics are nothing to write home about; they were pretty impressive back in 2006, but now they're considered dated and quirky (all the guys have muscles, all the girls have huge implants.. no idea why). HBM should pretty much run on anything of the last 8 or 9 years.. (egad, has it been that long already?)The Audio is pretty good. The soundtrack is very atmospheric, thanks to Jesper Kyd et al. The SFX are pretty standard and the voice acting is nice'n'hammy, which is just what you want from a Hitman game. The Storyline is surprisingly good. There are two seperate narrative strands that meet up right at the end for a climactic finish.To Summarise, if you're the kind of person that wants an immersive, challenging game that involves careful planning, clever distractions and devious, underhanded tactics, then look no further. HBM is a game full of little secrets, subtle jokes and peculiar quirks; it's a game that rewards you for your patience, and lets you play it how you want to. In HBM you can be the Sam Fisher style assassin sneaking in, doing the dirty deed and leaving, or you can be Chow Yun-Fat running in with your dual pistols and fancy suit, capping every bad guy in sight, but you can also be anything in between (as long as you terminate your targets and don't die! :p)-------------Overall: 4/5Audio: 3.5/5Graphics:  3/5Gameplay: 4.5/5

												Hitman Blood Money brings us the  return of Agent 47 as the cool, calm, calculating contract clipper of casual clusterf*cks,seriously though if you are looking for solid experience that allows you to switch almost seemlessly betwen 'sneaky, silent sabotage' like a true wetwork professional and 'knock the front door down with my raging todger and anything with a pulse and/or looks at me funny gets a lead creme brulee' like a gun toting austistic adolescent who has revently been given several red bull IV's then look no more, my good chum. The sprawling open levels and endless combinations of strategies allow you to try a multitude of different strategies, to name a few I myself have Poisoned donuts, Sniped a chicken man, knocked out a over zealous, horny housewife with animal tranquiliser, poured ether on a girls panties, come back from the dead and my personal favorite silently sniping a rich politician's son as he is sitting in a hot tub amongst bikini clad, bimbos with their pixilated cleavages out for the world to see.In closing, if you find yourself on the steam sales this week and deciding whether you should buy FF8 or Sleeping dogs i would suggest you save your money and buy Hitman: Blood Money, because more than anything else it is fun, remember fun? before you cared about HD graphics or Realistic face textures? Give me Garotting a mall santa or Infiltrating the chicken suit party at Mardi Gras over "oh my god his clothes actually look wet when he gets out of the water" anyday.Gameplay 9Graphics 6Sound 6.5Story 7Replay Value 9.5Final thought: The user makes this game, if you are an unimaginative asshat then perhaps you should stick to pwning nubs in Call Of Dooty. Otherwise I heartily recommend this game. 8/10

												Hitman blood money is an assassin game where you play as agent 47, a ruthless killing machine. This game has around 14 levels with different objectives, targets and maps. The best thing about this game is you can play to your style. Be silent or kill everyone on the map if you like. Get money, upgrade weapons and buy gadgets etc (nothing stupid like lasar watches). My critism for this game is there isn't that much replayability. I cant see playing more then around 40 hours. It only took me 14 to complete it on normal. 												Simply Stunning. the transition of coming from the outstanding absolution to another outstanding blood money was magnificent. it took a while of getting used to but the creativity of the levels and the way they are designed with multiple outcomes is superb. absolution was a linear game with roughly one outcome to each level; but what made up for that was the beutiful - emotional storyline which took a place in my heart. blood money provides almost a sandbox with each level and is mainly a trial and error basis. you fail, you try again. The more you fail the more knowledge you get on the level which enables more precise judgement of when to move, when to attack and when to do a certain act. whether its waiting for somebody to look away, or waiting for them to pass a precise spot. the pure essence of the game is all about timing. it's stunning! my advice is that if you muck up the first time don't leave the game and feel downhearted the game was designed for you to fail time and time again so you become more experienced on the levels.

ry 10, 2014
												It's a damn fine game, it has some flaws however.-The controls are a bit derpy at times, so you have to get used to them. -Gameplay wise, you get the option to choose/upgrade weapons, but can basically go around and kill everyone without ever taking out a gun (with a few exceptions to my knowledge). Every mission I've done so far can easily be done without shooting or getting shot, and in most cases if you do get caught, there will be an infinite barrage of guards streaming on your way, so I see the health bar as a joke.-There are many paths you can go by on each mission. There are different difficulties to choose from, but they barely make any difference. The real difficulty is playing the mission without buying any intel, as you will have to think of a tactic, find patterns, and play by trial and error. -There are a few guns to chose from before starting the mission and the only useful one is the pistol, as it is fast, concealable, and is more generally used. The sniper is on the exact other side of the spectrum: The are rarely any circumstances where it is needed. In the first mission, there is one time where I needed a sniper for some punk on a ferris wheel, ended up running right past him because I was a slow sniper. In the opera, I brought a sniper because I thought it would be fun to snipe the guy, and though I was hidden on the balcony on the highest floor, somebody had eagle vision or something and spotted me, wasn't spotted with the pistol.-The AI is alright, nothing special. Most everyone follows a pattern of movement, and there are some peculiar persons to see.I would give it a 7/10; Not for ninjas, not for commandos.

												my favorite out of all the Hitman games which is why I've gone back to this game SO MANY TIMES. No doubt the satisfaction is diminishing cuz i've played it so many times but still once in a while I'll pick a random mission for a "hit" and feel like I did my job as Agent 47.PROS:-pretty solid graphics for a 2006 game (even the visuals of the landscapes like the buildings in las vegas give a nice vibe)-many ways to kill targets so it feels freeing to choose to to dispose them (by a gun, fiberwire, or poison, etc...)-good music-nice to be able to choose  your loadout of weapons and you can customize them for improvement, which you can afford by completing missions. But doing so in a stealthier and less bloody way earns more money. Still, you can go on a shooting rampage if you want.CONS:-something minor that annoys me is the sound of one of the main pistols. Not the famous silverballers that 47 uses, but the other one featured in the game that gives a weak sound.-I've always kinda laughed at the first-person view in the Hitman games. the gun always looks smaller and weirdly shaped. they haven't really made it unoticable in this one imo.-things that 47 can do feels limited (though, remember this was a 2006 game) like better hand-to-hand combat (if you are unarmed and attack someone it is either grab their gun or if they are not pointing a gun at you it's headbutt, punch, punch); no choke holds in the game, so if you want to knock someone out without punching them, its using a sedative which you only have 2 uses per level; no hiding in corners to peak out; lock-picking is automatic; dragging an enemy body is slow. Bottom line, you ain't the most effective assassin out there ever.Overall, a highly replayable game. 9/10

3, 2014
												Hitman: Blood Money will keep you coming back to it's varied levels and the multiple ways to kill your targets. This is a true Hitman game and sticks to the mechanics of it's predecessors (And improves them greatly) The AI is not the smartest, but they suit the game's needs. Most reviews are terrible and just say "I dressed as a clown, 10/10" So here's all you need to hear:Blood Money isn't like most stealth games. You mainly hide in plain sight with disguises and trickery. Replayability is amazing, because of all the different ways to kill your targets and the different difficulty settings. You can also choose what weapons you want and customize them to your liking. You can run in with your guns out, shooting everything that moves or not use guns at all. It's all up to you and the game won't hold your hand and give you objectives for every single mission. *cough* Absolution *cough* Each mission will require some thinking and planning, but very rewarding I definitely recommend this game over Hitman: Aboslution. Absolution was just too linear and no room to mess around or do things on your own. Hitman: Blood Money is a fantastic game and you should buy it.

27, 2016
												The short version: get blood money. The long version isn't so simple. Every Hitman game introduces itself with an impressive amount of class and enjoyment. Those first two levels are always so promising. As the game progresses, however, those shining promises diminish onto bitter lies. The variety of weapons and tactics you learn would lead you to believe that every level will be thick with choices as to how you'll progress. There should be a variety of ways to kill your targets. There should be thought provoking scenarios that will make you feel like you've accomplished something upon completing them. Instead you're given two, maybe three ways to get within attack range of your target. From there you can do a "silent assasssin attack" that will rarely be something you'll figure out without immersion breaking trial and error. Instead you'll end up throwing a hammer at his/her head or just shooting them and running away with a terrified Zoidberg "whoop whoop whoop whoop!". I've never seen a sandbox game that so actively discourages exploration and experimentation. Enemies pop in and out of rooms with the predictability of pokemon in tall grass, the game intentionally thows you for a loop as to what disguise you'll need CONSTANTLY, and awkward fight controls make shooting your way out of anything a joke. In the end it is fun though. After pointlessly dying a thousand times each map becomes less chaotic and more predictable. The massive levels are very fun to run around in once you know where you're going. Killing your targets is usually satisfying which does give the game some replayability. The repetitive soundtrack is at least nice to listen to as well. All in all I just barely give this game three stars. The cool concept works well and the mechanics work often enough that you usually feel somewhat in control of what's happening. This game wouldn't be so infuriating if the immersion wasn't so good before it was ripped away by a bad design choice.

												The gamer in me would never let me sleep if I didnt praise this game at least in the smallest degree. Hitman Bloodmoney puts the player in the mind of Agent 47, A Clone who works as, you guessed it, a hitman. While earlier games may or may not have been great (i've heard good things about the second hitman and Contracts was fun), this game is just shy of being my favorite PC game of all time. While there are missions rather than a completely open world game, Blood Money gives you the option of completing the mission in a slew of unique, sometimes humorous ways. Before each mission you are given a list of objectives (which may update on the go) and a chance to choose what weapons you bring and the option to upgrade them with money you earn from each mission.

I havn't played the new 2016 game but it looks like they copied alot of Blood Moneys mechanics and threw away that awful Absolution idea, which is great.Everything about the setup was perfect, upgrading weapons before it was common place in games, hop in any mission you want as long as you are that far in the game at any difficulty you want on the fly aswell as the missions being relatively short depending on your play style. Free form gameplay where you can either just gun your way through every level or sneak your way through and you get a rating afterwards based on your actions. It was really one of my favorite games from one of the best devs of the era IO interactive was really on their game back then. Shame Freedom Fighters isn't on steam.

												I've played a lot of stealth games, and I've loved a lot of stealth games. Whether it was cleaning up the streets of Hell's Kitchen in Deus Ex, sneaking past Hammerites in Thief, or assassinating tall boys in Dishonored, I'm no stranger to how a stealth game works. Stick to the shadows. Avoid lines of sight. Analyze a room. Clear the sector of all guards and move onto the next.Imagine my surprise when I played Hitman: Blood Money.H:BM features a completely fresh and unique look on stealth games in something I just haven't quite seen before. The name of the game is hiding in plain sight--mixing yourself in crowds and seeking out your targets without attention. Player emergence runs wild in a game with absolutely no objective markers, yet an insurmountable amount of options and paths. Each level is sprawling and huge, with tons of people littering the landscapes. Seriously, this engine is capable of putting a lot of people in a room. Each level has dozens of ways to complete it, whether it's you slipping by with a few guards hot on your tail, or you absolutely slaughtering an entire area, or just you walking amongst others while causing "accidents."Not only is it such a fun romp to go through, but levels offer so much replayability, that you're probably going to come back for seconds, or perhaps even thirds.Buy it.

content:
5, 2016
Still The BestHitman has always been about two basic things; stealth and killing. Truly the series has become iconic since its original release 16 years ago. This game is, in my opinion, the apex of the series, tying the finest of all the games in the series together brilliantly. A swan song perhaps as this was last in the series before IO had been bought, along with this franchise, by SquareEnix.In this game Agent 47 returns in a series of missions as recounted during an interview and flashbacks between a reporter and the former director for the FBI. The story is actually interesting and builds to a pretty unique conclusion. The missions and settings are well diverse if not seemingly nonsensically strung together. As agent 47 it is up to the player to decide how ton carry out these missions.If the player chooses to go in guns blazing, there will be witnesses which will more than affect the mission and the score, it will also affect future missions via 'Notoriety'. The more notorious Agent 47 becomes the harder missions may also become as guards and civilians will be more suspicious, making the stealth aspect all the more difficult.If the player chooses to be stealthy the game really shines. Watching guard patterns and memorizing hiding places is only part of the challenge. Often there are alternative ways into and out of areas, or little secrets to ferret out that might make performing the mission more interesting. Intel may be bought with cash earned on missions that will offer tips or clues as to where items may be stashed for use, or a secret about the target or people in the area that might prove handy. Ultimately these are not necessary as the player has many options to take advantage of. The truly masterful player can earn higher ratings and less notoriety if hits are performed as covertly as possible, or better yet, made to appear as 'accidents'. Disguises are also fun, and a bit silly, but then what could possibly be out of place when a six foot tall, frowning bald man with a bar-code on his head dresses like Santa and pours an aphrodisiac into another guy's drink?At the end of each mission the player's performance is evaluated in the form of a newspaper page, which is also loaded with Easter eggs regarding the story and game. Fire a lot of bullets and the story about the assassination will describe the killer as unprofessional, amateurish, even sloppy. Little touches like this really help set the experience apart from other games, lending humor and finesse to the scoring system that, even ten years after the initial release, remains very unique.There are issues, however. The game is, as mentioned, over ten years old, having been first released in spring 2006. The graphics are very dated, though this does nothing to really hurt the game itself. Other problems are bigger, but still not really too bad. The AI can behave a little oddly, at times I'd seen a civilian simply standing in place like a mannequin with their arms out, then suddenly come to life and begin freaking out. Other times the guards might inexplicably repeat a task and throw off their routine, making the mission a bit harder as the game does not play out as it was intended. It was a curve-ball, but I didn't mind the added challenge of trying to work around something totally unexpected. Some of the animations are aggravatingly overdone, making Agent 47 kind of take his time doing certain things rather needlessly. Pulling a fuse isn't just pulling a fuse; it's him opening the box, reaching into the box with a kind of unnecessary flourish, peering around, pulling out the fuses, peering around again, and closing the fuse box. This is the kind of thing that can get the player discovered and feels aggravating. Again, not a game breaking issue, but in a game where timing is important I’d like for things to move a little more simply and less like a lengthy ballet. Again, not a game breaker, but still very annoying.Overall this is a fantastic game with a lot to offer stealth fans, and everything Hitman fans love about the series. Recommended!Pros: High replay value Satisfying no matter how you choose to complete missions Excellent musical score by Jesper Kyd Controls are excellent Missions are fun Rewards practice and experience Good story Cons: Graphically dated Lengthy animations for tasks Some bugs can break missions forcing restarts Sometimes wonky AI No achievements (if you care about that) No game pad supportI have played three version of this game; first on Xbox, then Xbox 360 (with all achievements), and now finally on PC. This is the best in the series, perfectly executed...(pun intended.)

Whether it was cleaning up the streets of Hell's Kitchen in Deus Ex, sneaking past Hammerites in Thief, or assassinating tall boys in Dishonored, I'm no stranger to how a stealth game works. Stick to the shadows. Avoid lines of sight. Analyze a room. Clear the sector of all guards and move onto the next.Imagine my surprise when I played Hitman: Blood Money.H:BM features a completely fresh and unique look on stealth games in something I just haven't quite seen before. The name of the game is hiding in plain sight--mixing yourself in crowds and seeking out your targets without attention. Player emergence runs wild in a game with absolutely no objective markers, yet an insurmountable amount of options and paths. Each level is sprawling and huge, with tons of people littering the landscapes. Seriously, this engine is capable of putting a lot of people in a room. Each level has dozens of ways to complete it, whether it's you slipping by with a few guards hot on your tail, or you absolutely slaughtering an entire area, or just you walking amongst others while causing "accidents."Not only is it such a fun romp to go through, but levels offer so much replayability, that you're probably going to come back for seconds, or perhaps even thirds.Buy it.

content:
r 25, 2014
												It is in the Top 2 best Hitman games yet. Compared to Absolution (which was broken up into smaller, but yet more replayable missions), it is a lot bigger. It also includes a Loadout selection screen in which you can choose what weapons and upgrades you want for the mission. (I wish they brought that into Absolution as maybe a Black Market). Other than really those things, Absolution is better. Graphics, (because it's newer), characters, story, more "fun" levels (you know the ones), and the aspect of having to collect your gadgets through levels was cool. Thankfully in Absolution, there is a few huge levels, like the Hotel Terminus, Town (forgot the full name), and a few more. This seems like a review for both games, but this is 100% true. (In my opinion) Thanks for reading!Pros:-LOADOUTS (Now you can take in any weapon or gadget for the job!)-Open Levels (Absolution's were more "linear")-First Person (Was stripped from Absolution, maybe it was too buggy for that game?)Cons:-Dated Graphics-Mediocre Story (Just a bunch of Contracts)-Less detailed (that is the trade off they did with Absolution)It's a matter of preference, modern vs old-school/retro. I would start with Absolution with this becoming the second pick.

												The game is amazing, however, it should be noted - including on the store page - that the game is glitching and not working properly in many machines. Search the forums and you'll see variations of the same story: At the end of the first mission, the game crashes. Some people posted alleged fixes, and while some had limited or otherwise temporary success with them (the game would crash after another mission, for instance), the one I tried has not worked. No one seems to know exactly what's going on with this game, but it is very frustrating that you have to replay the same first level to know if some config you changed helped in any way, shape or form. I don't actually know how widespread this problem is (as I said, no one seems to know for certain why this is happening), but I guess the publisher could at least inform the consumer on the store page, for crying out loud. I know it is a somewhat old game, but you are charging money for this nonetheless.If you can play Blood Money, well, firstly, I envy you, as it is one of the greats in the "medium-sized franchises" side of the videogame world. I believe other informative reviews here and elsewhere could ellaborate on it better than I could.PS: As it stands, I can't recommend the purchase of this game, as the problems seems to be fairly common and, as of now, unsolved.
